titleStmt.title: John W. Power et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG1782

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Appointments by the Governor, Civil Appointments, 1863-1867

body.p:
To the Honorable Thos E Bramlette.
Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky.

The undersigned citizens of the First district of Mason County do respectfully state that by the death of Esquire William Greathouse which occurred some two weeks since a vacancy was caused in the office of Magistrate in said precinct. It is very necessary that an appointment should be immediately made, then being at present only two magistrates in the 2 Maysville precincts one in each, and one of them absent at least half of the time from the County, and we would represent that John L Grant acted as magistrate for some years previous to the Election of William Greathouse deceased and recommend him as a suitable person for the office. We also suggest that the appointment be made by the 20th of this month in time for March business --

John W Power
Wm J Ross
A J Newell
W. P. Watkins
William McKinley
J. M. Rains
Thos R Calvert
Henry L. Newell
Keith Berry
J. S. Martin
Lim Gurney
James Surge
Joseph Ryan
Edward A Olivet
Jno D Taylor
T J. Prince
G W Tudor
Georg Baner
J. W. Orr
Calvin Cromwell
W T Tolle
M. T. Cockrell
Geo. W. Dulser
J. A. Richardson
Wm Edmond
Pole Heplhen
Hugh McCaultary
Abner Bowling
J Dickson
W P Wolford
J Myers
James Holiday
W H Wallingford
Henry Williams
George Potter
J L P Harnwell
John Grant was Justice of the peace for 2 or 3 yrs preceding the Election of Esquire Greathouse and will do about as well as any one who will accept it.

Your very truly
W H Savage
Judge of County Court
I was requested to send this to you.

Mason Co
J. P
Appt
13th Feby 1864
